p: Many viruses persistently transmitted by arthropods cause serious diseases in plants, animals and humans. More than 76% of plant viruses and 40% of mammalian viruses are transmitted to the hosts by specific arthropods, mainly planthoppers, aphids, mosquitoes, and ticks [ 1, 2]. Frequent epidemics of viral diseases in rice, wheat and vegetables are largely attributed to high populations and viral transmission efficiency of the insect vectors [ 3– 6]. Similarly, viruses that cause diseases in humans and animals such as dengue fever, Zika fever and Japanese encephalitis, are vectored by different species of Aedes mosquitoes and are endemic in many areas of the developing world [ 7– 10]. Understanding the virus–insect vector interaction and transmission mechanisms will provide important information on the epidemics of the diseases caused by plant and animal arboviruses and lead to the development of better control strategies.
